lesson.name: Lesson 8.12 Teacher Guide: Using Technology to Find the Quadratic Regression

page.title: 8.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In an earlier lesson, students used scatter plots to perform linear regression on a data set. In this lesson, students will familiarize themselves with graphing technology in order to display a data set modeling a quadratic function. They will learn how to use this graphing technology to analyze the data set and generate an equation for a curve of best fit. These equations, modeling real-world situations, can be used to make predictions about those situations.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Use graphing technology, such as Desmos, to input a data set modeling a quadratic function and display a scatter plot of the data.
  • Generate an quadratic equation for a curve of best, or regression curve, using graphing technology.
  • Analyze a situation modeled by a quadratic function and use a curve of best fit to make predictions about that situation.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Graph a quadratic data set using technology.
  • Find a regression curve, or curve of best fit, using a quadratic data set.
  • Use a regression curve to create a quadratic model for making predictions.
  • Make predictions about a real-world situation using a quadratic data set.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(B) write, using technology, quadratic functions that provide a reasonable fit to data to estimate solutions and make predictions for real-world problems.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 8.12.1: Graphing a Quadratic Data Set Using Technology
  • 8.12.2: Finding the Curve of Best Fit
    • 8.12.2: Self Check
    • 8.12.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.12.3: Making Predictions Using a Quadratic Model
    • 8.12.3: Self Check
    • 8.12.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.12.4: Finding the Missing Data in the Set

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 8.12.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil
  • Graphing technology
  • Master List of Data Sets: Lesson 8.12

Required Preparation

  • Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • quadratic function
  • variable
  • scatter plot
  • curve of best fit
  • quadratic regression

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their curiosity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Curiosity Counts
  • Seeing Red

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Curiosity from Character Lab.

page.title: 8.12.1: Graphing a Quadratic Data Set Using Technology
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up serves two purposes. The first is to familiarize the students with Desmos as a graphing technology, if they have not already used it. Desmos is a useful graphing tool that has been referenced in previous lessons. The second is to introduce how to input a data set into a table so that it may be graphed, forming a scatter plot.

Launch

Arrange students in pairs or groups, if necessary, so they have access to Desmos. If possible, allow students to work individually so that each understands the steps necessary to graph a data set.

After students open a window to Desmos, instruct them to click into each cell in the table and insert each corresponding value in the data set. Once a student has clicked into the first cell in the table, they may also use the arrow keys to navigate from one cell to the next. 

Instructions are provided if they wish to copy and paste the entire table, but emphasize that unless the values are copied from a spreadsheet, they will not be pasted together into the table.

Show students that the graphing window, or field of view, may be changed by clicking onto the graph and dragging it in different directions.

Student Activity

  1. Click on the Desmos link to generate a table for entering a data set.

Desmos: Quadratic Data Set Table

  1. Enter the data set shown in the table below into the corresponding \(x_1\) and \(y_1\) columns. 

(If preferred, the data can be copied and pasted into Desmos from a spreadsheet using keyboard shortcuts. Windows: Ctrl+C for copy and Ctrl+V for paste. Mac: Command+C for copy and Command+V for paste.)

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

1

2

2

5

3

10

4

17

5

26

The window should be appropriately set to display the points in the table, but sometimes it will be necessary to adjust the window of the graph in order to properly view your data set. Use the mouse to drag and change the viewing window. To zoom in or out, use the buttons in the top right or the scrolling wheel on the mouse.

  1. Examine the data for a pattern that might fit any quadratic function that you recognize. What equation do you hypothesize would best fit these data points?

Answer: The data match the quadratic function \(y = x^2+ 1\).

In this lesson, we will learn to use technology to analyze a data set, find a curve of fit, and make predictions about a situation given the data that we have.

Activity Synthesis

If students are having difficulty finding the pattern in the data set, tell them to square the \(x\)-value and compare the result to the \(y\)-value.

If students think the data look like a linear pattern, graph the equation \(y = x^2+ 1\) on the same graph to demonstrate that the points match the quadratic function perfectly. Inform students that while these data match the function exactly, the data in this lesson will not perfectly align to the functions we find. The functions we find using the data sets in this lesson will be a close fit, but never an exact match.

Ask students to predict the \(y\)-value of the function if the \(x\)-value is 6. (37)

Tell students, in this lesson, we will use a data set to find an equation to represent those data. We will then use that equation to make predictions about other values that might fit into the data set.

page.title: 8.12.2: Finding the Curve of Best Fit
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

In this activity, students continue to familiarize themselves with the process of entering information into Desmos. They use quadratic regression on a data set to find the equation of a curve of best fit. 

In the next activity, they will use a similar curve of best fit to make predictions about a situation.

Launch

Arrange students in pairs or groups, if necessary, so they have access to Desmos. If possible, allow students to work individually so that each understands the steps necessary to find a curve of best fit.

Read the activity introduction as a class. Ask students if they remember finding the line of best fit of a data set. Introduce the new vocabulary words. Tell students they have already used linear regression in a previous lesson, and they will now use quadratic regression.

Allow students to open the graphed data set in Desmos and answer question 2. If possible, display the graph for the class to see. Read each bullet point in question 3 before entering the equation. Demonstrate the keys pressed to accurately enter the equation, \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\).  Then, if possible, instruct students to enter the equation on their own screens.

Allow students to complete questions 5–9 on their own. Remind them that exponents may be entered using the ^ symbol.

For English language learners, display the keys that need to be pressed to enter the equation for the curve of best fit:

y

1

~

a

x

1

^

2

+

b

x

1

+

c

Reinforce that the Shift button will need to be held down first when pressing the ~ symbol.

Student Activity

In a previous lesson, you learned how to find the line of best fit. A line of best fit is a line on a graph that best approximates the equation of the points in a data set or scatter plot.

In this activity, we will learn how to find the curve of best fit, which is the curve modeled by the equation that best approximates the points in a data set or scatter plot. Since our data set is based on a quadratic function, we must use a curve instead of a line. This process, called quadratic regression, is the process of determining the equation of a parabola that best fits a data set.

  1. Click on the Desmos link to show the data set.

Desmos: The Data Set

  1. Examine the data. Do they appear to you to form a line or a curve?

Answer: They appear to be the start of a curve.

  1. We will use graphing technology to find a curve of best fit. Click the pointer below the table into entry box #2 to enter a new function. The cursor should start blinking. Enter the equation:

\(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\)  

  • Notice that when you type the 1 after \(y\) or \(x\), Desmos automatically places it as subscript.
  • Also notice that we are not using an equal sign. The symbol ~ means approximately and tells Desmos to approximate a line or curve of best fit. It should be in the top-left corner of your keyboard, and you might press it using the Shift button. If you are using the Desmos on-screen keyboard, it will be on the ABC keyboard.
  • After pressing the subscript 1 after the \(y\) and the first \(x\), use the ^ symbol to tell Desmos you would like to enter an exponent.
  1. Once you have entered the curve of best fit, you can press Enter. The curve of best fit will appear. Your screen will look like this:

If something has gone wrong, you can catch up by clicking the link shown here:

Desmos: The Curve of Best Fit

  1. Look in the lower-left corner of the screen. We will use the \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) values to construct the equation for our curve of best fit.
  1. What is the value of \(a\) rounded to the nearest hundredth?

Answer: -0.86

  1. What is the value of \(b\) rounded to the nearest hundredth?

Answer: 8.09

  1. What is the value of \(c\) rounded to the nearest hundredth?

Answer: 16.53

  1. Write an equation in the form \(y = ax^2+ bx + c\) for the curve of best fit using the values you found.

Answer: \(y = -0.86x^2 + 8.09x + 16.53\)

This is the equation for your curve of best fit.

You may notice the \(R^2\) value. The closer this value is to 1, the better your curve of best fit matches the data set. The \(R^2\) value for this data set is 0.9972. Since this value is relatively close to 1, this curve of best fit is a reasonably accurate match to the data set. 

Activity Synthesis

Reinforce the idea that the curve of best fit does not precisely align with each point in the data set. In other words, no point in the data set is guaranteed to fall exactly onto the curve of best fit. 

Inform students that while the \(R^2\) value is an important measurement of how closely the curve of best fit matches the data set, we will not be using it in this lesson.

To review key ideas from the activity, discuss questions such as:

  • If you graph the equation, \(y = -0.86x^2 + 8.09x + 16.53\), into Desmos, how will it compare to the curve of best fit shown on the screen now? (It will be nearly identical, aside from rounding differences, to the curve of best fit that was derived using the equation, \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\).)
  • What do you think would happen if you changed one of the values in the data set? (Changing the value of a point in the data set would change the equation of the curve of best fit. It would no longer be \(y = -0.86x^2 + 8.09x + 16.53\).)

Use Desmos to demonstrate that by changing a value in one point of the data set even slightly, the curve of best fit changes.

8.12.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Click on the Desmos link to show a data set. Find the equation of the curve of best fit. Round each coefficient to the nearest hundredth.

Desmos: Finding the Curve of Best Fit

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(y = -0.92x^2+ 4.25x + 8.36\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Did you enter \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\) to find the curve of best fit? The answer is \(y = -0.94x^2+ 4.51x + 16.96\).

\(y = -0.97x^2+ 7.62x + 19.34\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Did you enter \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\) to find the curve of best fit? The answer is \(y = -0.94x^2+ 4.51x + 16.96\).

\(y = -0.94x^2+ 4.51x + 16.96\)

That's correct! Check yourself: The graph of the curve lines up with the data set as closely as possible.

\(y = -0.91x^2 + 2.23x + 16.42\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Did you enter \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\) to find the curve of best fit? The answer is \(y = -0.94x^2+ 4.51x + 16.96\).

8.12.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Finding the Curve of Best Fit

Let's find the curve of best fit for a given data set.

Click on the Desmos link to open a graph.

Desmos: New Data Set

Step 1
Click the + symbol in the top left and select a table.

Enter the data set as shown. Press Enter.

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

1

99.7

2

130

3

149

4

172

9

175

11

140

The data set will populate the graph as shown here.

Step 2   
On the left side, click in box #2 for a new item. Enter the instruction line below to generate a curve of best fit.

\(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\)

  • Remember from the activity that Desmos will automatically place the 1 as subscript after an \(x\) or \(y\).
  • Don't forget to use the symbol ~ that means approximately.
  • Use the ^ symbol to enter an exponent.

As soon as you enter the instruction line, Desmos will generate the curve of best fit.

Step 3
Use the coefficients generated to write the equation for the curve of best fit.

Round each coefficient to the nearest hundredth. 

The curve of best fit is \(y = -2.76x^2+ 37.04x + 65.66\).

Try It: Finding the Curve of Best Fit

Click on the Desmos link to show a data set. Find the equation of the curve of best fit. Round each coefficient to the nearest hundredth.

Desmos: Try It - Data Set

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the curve of best fit:

Solve for the curve of best fit by entering \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\). 

The curve of best fit is \(y = 6.18x^2+ 4.59x + 25.42\).

page.title: 8.12.3: Making Predictions Using a Quadratic Model
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity takes quadratic regression a step further by using a data set that models a real-world situation. Students will model the data set representing the flight of a helium balloon by creating a scatter plot, find the equation of a curve of best fit, and use that equation to make predictions about the balloon’s flight.

Launch

Arrange students in pairs or groups, if necessary, so they have access to Desmos. If possible, allow students to work individually so that each understands the steps necessary to make predictions using a curve of best fit.

This activity starts from the beginning in Desmos, allowing students to create a table and then populate it with the data set representing the balloon’s flight. Gauge students’ comfort with entering the data set and finding the curve of best fit. Review the steps as needed while allowing students to complete the first two questions. 

Pause the class and be sure that students have correctly entered the data and generated a curve of best fit before moving to question 3.

Allow students quiet think time as they attempt question 3. Reinforce the idea that they can enter the equation \(x = 4\) into Desmos to help them solve the problem. After discussing the solution to question 3 as a class, allow students time to complete the remaining questions.

Student Activity

A helium balloon is released and floats up before coming back down to the ground.

The following data set shows the height in feet, \(y\), of the balloon corresponding to the number of minutes passed, \(x\).

\(x_1\) (minutes)

\(y_1\) (height in feet)

1

99.7

1.5

130

3

149

4.5

172

7

108

9

84

  1. Use the Desmos link below. Click the + symbol in the top left and select a table. Enter the data set into the table.

Desmos: Balloon Flight

  1. Use the instruction line, \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\), to find the curve of best fit.

What is the equation of the curve of best fit? Round coefficients to the nearest hundredth.

Answer: \(y = -3.97x^2+35.22x + 78.63\)

  1. How high will the balloon be after 4 minutes? (Hint: Graph the line \(x = 4\) to help identify where it intersects with the curve of best fit.)

Answer: Approximately 156.0 feet

  1. How high will the balloon be after 10 minutes?

Answer: Approximately 33.83 feet

  1. At what time will the balloon first be at a height of 95 feet? (Graph the line \(y = 95\).)

Answer: At approximately 0.49 minute

  1. At what time will the balloon return to a height of 95 feet?

Answer: At approximately 8.38 minutes

  1. When will the balloon reach the ground, or have a height of 0 feet?

Answer: At approximately 10.72 minutes

Video: Using Technology to Find The Quadratic Regression

Watch the following video to learn more about finding quadratic regression. 



Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may assume that the data set models a symmetrical flight of the balloon from the ground up to a maximum height and back down to the ground. Show where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis, or where time equals 0 minutes. Emphasize that at the start of this data set, or \(x = 0\), the balloon already had a height of approximately 78.6 feet.

Activity Synthesis

To review key ideas from the activity, discuss questions such as:

  • “How does graphing an additional line on the coordinate plane help to visualize making a prediction using the curve of best fit?” (The line that is being graphed represents a given \(x\)- or \(y\)-value in the situation. By finding its intersection point with the curve of best fit, the corresponding \(x\)- or \(y\)-value is determined.)
  • “In the activity, what does a vertical line with the equation \(x = 8\) represent?” (It represents the moment in the balloon’s flight when 8 minutes have passed.)
  • “In the activity, what does a vertical line with the equation \(y = 36\) represent?” (It represents the moment or moments in the balloon’s flight when it has a height of 36 feet.)

8.12.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

A baseball is thrown into the air. The following data set shows the height in feet, \(y\), of the baseball corresponding to the number of seconds passed, \(x\).

            Desmos: Baseball Flight

Approximately how long will it be before the baseball hits the ground?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

2.73 seconds

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the time it takes the baseball to reach its maximum height. The answer is 5.74 seconds.

5.74 seconds

That’s correct! Check yourself: The curve of best fit is \(y = -3.93x^2+ 21.46x + 6.09\). The curve intersects the \(x\)-axis at 5.74.

6.75 seconds

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The curve of best fit is \(y = -3.93x^2+ 21.46x + 6.09\). The curve intersects the \(x\)-axis at 5.74. The answer is 5.74 seconds.

7.18 seconds

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The curve of best fit is \(y = -3.93x^2+ 21.46x + 6.09\). The curve intersects the \(x\)-axis at 5.74. The answer is 5.74 seconds.

8.12.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Making Predictions Using a Quadratic Model

A filtration system is being tested in a new aquarium. A pollutant is continuously added to the aquarium, and the filtration system is turned on until it has removed all of the pollutant from the water.

The following data set shows the milliliters (mL) of pollutant present, \(y\), corresponding to the number of minutes that have passed, \(x\), since the experiment started.

Desmos: Aquarium Pollutant

Let’s enter the instruction line, \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\), to find the curve of best fit.

The curve of best fit is determined to be \(y = -0.29x^2+ 37.74x + 95.95\).

We can use this curve of best fit to answer questions and make predictions about the amount of pollutant that will be in the water (mL) and the time it takes to completely clean the tank of pollutant.

How many mL of pollutant will be in the water after 12 minutes?

  • To answer this question, we want to know the \(y\)-value on the curve of best fit when the \(x\)-value is 12.
  • We can graph the line \(x = 12\) and see where it intersects with the curve of best fit.

  • By moving the cursor over the intersection point, we see that the \(y\)-value is approximately 507.49.
  • This means that after 12 minutes, there will be approximately 507.49 mL of pollutant in the water.

At what time(s) will there be 1000 mL of pollutant in the water?

  • To answer this question, we want to know the \(x\)-value on the curve of best fit when the \(y\)-value is 1000.
  • We can graph the line \(y = 1000\) and see where it intersects with the curve of best fit.

  • The line \(y = 1000\) intersects with the curve of best fit at two points. This means there are two times when there is 1000 mL of pollutant. We see that the \(x\)-values are approximately 31.51 and 99.91.
  • In other words, there will be 1000 mL of pollutant at approximately 31.51 minutes and again at approximately 99.91 minutes after the experiment starts.

How long after the experiment has started will the filtration system have removed all of the pollutant from the aquarium?

  • To answer this question, we want to know the \(x\)-value of the \(x\)-intercept of the curve of best fit.
  • If we graph \(y = 0\), we can click on the intersection point to find its coordinates. The \(x\)-intercept of the curve of best fit is \((133.92, 0)\).
  • So, approximately 133.92 minutes after the experiment starts, there will be no pollutant left in the water.

Try It: Making Predictions Using a Quadratic Model

Use the same data set from the example in the section above.

Desmos: Aquarium Pollutant

The data set shows the milliliters (mL) of pollutant present, \(y\), corresponding to the number of minutes that have passed, \(x\), since the experiment started.

  1. How many mL of pollutant will be in the water after 47 minutes?
  1. At what time(s) will there be 1215 mL of pollutant in the water?

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to use graphing technology and the curve of best fit to make predictions about a situation:

  1. After 47 minutes, there will be approximately 1235.41 mL of pollutant.
  1. There will be 1215 mL of pollutant in the water after approximately 45.19 minutes and 86.23 minutes.

page.title: 8.12.4: Finding the Missing Data in the Set
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

Thomasina used a quadratic data set to create a curve of best fit for her data. Then she accidentally spilled paint on her paper and lost some of the entries in the table.

Desmos: Thomasina's Curve of Best Fit

She needs to work backward to fill in the missing entries in her data set. Use the curve of best fit she created to complete the table.

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

6

452.06

632.24

58.2

176.12

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answers:

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

6

188.07

17.9

452.06

31.1

632.24

58.2

630.83

83.6

176.12

page.title: 8.12.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

Use Desmos to answer questions 1–4. Find the curve of best fit for each data set. Round coefficients to the nearest hundredth.

  1.  

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

2

56

5

116

8

155

11

205

17

230

  • \(y = -0.93x^2+ 22.63x + 10.48\)
  • \(y = -0.69x^2+ 24.83x + 8.07\)
  • \(y = -3.11x^2+ 16.32x + 8.94\)
  • \(y = -0.7x^2 + 35.93x + 8.19\)

Answer: \(y = -0.69x^2+ 24.83x + 8.07\)

  1.  

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

3

105

9

250

14

349

23

400

37

258

  • \(y = -0.56x^2+ 38.74x + 5.31\)
  • \(y = -2.31x^2+ 24.711x + 3.25\)
  • \(y = -0.62x^2+ 17.45x + 9.64\)
  • \(y = -0.74x^2+ 34.32x + 7.44\)

Answer: \(y = -0.74x^2+ 34.32x + 7.44\)

  1.  

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

0.2

6.5

0.35

6.74

0.66

6.31

1

4.95

1.5

1.2

  • \(y = -6.3x^2+ 8x + 10.6\)
  • \(y = -3.1x^2+ 2.6x + 7.93\)
  • \(y = -4.31x^2+ 3.2x + 6.08\)
  • \(y = -5.1x^2 + 9.2x + 7.14\)

Answer: \(y = -4.31x^2+ 3.2x + 6.08\)

  1.  

\(x_1\)

\(y_1\)

0.3

25

0.6

36

1.2

45

1.8

33

2.3

12

  • \( y = -25.41x^2+ 59.28x + 9.64\)
  • \(y = -30.84x^2+ 49.61x + 8.99\)
  • \(y = -3.72x^2 + 7.34x + 8.67\)
  • \(y = -35.78x^2+ 45.21x + 3.74\)

Answer: \(y = -25.41x^2+ 59.28x + 9.64\)

For questions 5–9, use the following information.

The path of a toy rocket after launch is modeled by the following data set.

Desmos: Toy Rocket.

The height of the rocket, in feet, \(y\), corresponds to the number of seconds passed, \(x\).

  1. What is the equation for the curve of best fit that models the flight of the toy rocket?
  • \( y = -6.1x^2+ 31x + 1.24\)
  • \(y = -11.9x^2+ 30.2x + 3.64\)
  • \(y = -4.2x^2 + 34x + 6.34\)
  • \(y = -9.2x^2+ 46x + 3.51\)

Answer: \(y = -9.2x^2+ 46x + 3.51\)

  1. Approximately how high will the rocket be 2 seconds after launch?
  • 45.91 feet
  • 53.60 feet
  • 58.71 feet
  • 61.00 feet

Answer: 58.71 feet

  1. At what approximate times after launch will the rocket have a height of 20 feet?
  • 0.26 seconds after launch and 4.74 seconds after launch
  • 0.39 seconds after launch and 4.61 seconds after launch
  • 0.52 seconds after launch and 4.48 seconds after launch
  • 0.82 seconds after launch and 4.18 seconds after launch

Answer: 0.39 seconds after launch and 4.61 seconds after launch

  1. Approximately how long will it take the rocket to reach its maximum height?
  • 1.73 seconds
  • 2.50 seconds
  • 3.20 seconds
  • 5.08 seconds

Answer: 2.50 seconds

  1. Approximately how long will it take for the rocket to land on the ground?
  • 2.50 seconds
  • 4.63 seconds
  • 5.08 seconds
  • 6.12 seconds

Answer: 5.08 seconds

For question 10, Maria has found a curve of best fit using Desmos.

  1. Maria is asked to predict the \(y\)-value on her curve when \(x = 10\). To do this, she graphs the function \(x = 10\) and analyzes the intersection point of the curve and the line.

What is the \(y\)-value Maria is asked to predict?

  • 10
  • 93
  • 105
  • 111

Answer: 111

page.title: 8.12.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
A key takeaway from this lesson is the idea that we can use a data set that models a quadratic equation to represent a real-life situation. We can then find a curve of best fit to represent the data set. Additionally, we can then use that curve of best fit to make further predictions about that situation.

To help reinforce ideas from the lesson, review the following questions:

  • "How can one represent a data set using graphing technology?" (By inputting the data into a table in the graphing technology to create a scatter plot.)
  • "What does entering the equation \(y_1 \sim ax_1^2+bx_1+ c\) into a Desmos graph containing a data set representing a quadratic equation do?" (A curve of best fit will be generated.)
  • "Will each point in a data set representing a quadratic equation fall onto its corresponding curve of best fit? Explain your answer." (No, the curve of best fit represents the quadratic equation that best models all of the points in a data set. There is no guarantee that any individual point will align onto the curve.)
  • "Imagine a curve of best fit is graphed representing the height in meters, \(y\), of a projectile corresponding to the number of seconds passed, \(x\)."
  • "What does a vertical line with the equation \(x = 5\) intersecting with the curve of best fit represent?" (It represents the moment in the projectile's flight when 5 seconds have passed.)

    • "What does a horizontal line with the equation \(y = 10\) intersecting with the curve of best fit represent?" (It represents the moment or moments in the projectile's flight when it has a height of 10 feet.)

    • Tell students that many situations can be modeled by a data set representing a quadratic function. Using graphing technology to analyze these data sets and generate an equation for the curve of best fit is an important skill. The curve of best fit can be used to make accurate predictions about these situations.
